data.text: Where to Store Equipment when Sightseeing on a Bike Tour?
Where do people store their tent, sleeping back etc. when wild camping? if you want to go the town/village to go to the pub, sight seeing, go hiking or whatever.

In whatever you packed it in on your bike? My loadout is always sleep system/tent in the saddlebag because it does the best job of packing down into the smallest section closest to the seatpost. Tent is always the first to go up so its the last to go in. My tent packs incredibly small though, probably the size of a waterbottle (minus the pole). The pole goes in my (half) frame bag. If you're talking leaving your campsite setup and then going to the pub/cafe, sightseeing, exploring.....I guess it depends where you are.....For me, that's not common practice. My bike goes with me wherever I go with the exception of a toilet or into a grocery..and even then..
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: i want to do stuff when i get there i can't see the point otherwise tbh
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: Well you just have to consider if anyone stumbles upon your "goldmine". They're likely going to be cautious to see if anyone is around first, but likely leave with the bike.... The essence of wild camping is obviously for nobody to know you're there. If your possesions are hidden well enough 99 times out of 100 it will be there when you return, but all it takes is that one time where someone has a thief mentality and your stuff is gone....then what's the strategy? It's not so different than parking your commuter bike outside a building locked to a post only to come out and see the wheels and seatpost/saddle are missing. Stuff can happen when you leave opportunities for people to take advantage of the situatioin. If I go to a pub/cafe by bike....I sit on the patio/garden close to my bike/gear...which I do often because here in Belgium with the summer we've been having, but the bike doesn't exactly leave my sight. If trhey don't have a patio/garden, I find a different place to eat/drink.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: Ok cool
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: My first tour to the seaside is more about saving money getting there by not having to fill up with petrol. Than it is about the cycling in itself.
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: if you're in a built up area I hear bike shops will sometimes store your stuff, if in the wilderness well just stash it if you wanna risk that.
data.author: Danya Anderson Adams

data.text: thanks i thought about stashing stuff in a bush. I think if its well hidden the chances of stuff getting solen is minimal.
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: consider a camo tarp or a military camo netting.
data.author: Joshua Miller

data.text: I can dig it I like bike parks but it's rubbish doing fun trails loaded with 30lb of gear. Let's just say there are hidey holes everywhere.....
data.author: Danya Anderson Adams

data.text: hide it - liklihood of somebody coming across it and taking it quite slim unless you're in a crime hotspot. usually in the middle of nowhere you'll be ok.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: yeah cheers

data.text: It's kinda cheeky but you could ask a hotel to store it for you and offer to pay, or even go to a leisure centre and use a locker.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: yep the leisure cente is a good one
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: added bonus you can then have a shower there too!
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: YeahðŸ™‚
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: Find out if thereâ€™s a bike shop in the area you want to visit. They are more likely to help out a fellow cyclist and mind your bike than anyone else. Perhaps buy a few bits from them or a 6 pack of beer and they will likely hold your bike for the day while you explore. Be respectful of their hours
data.author: Andrew Cutts

data.text: It isnâ€™t an option everywhere but sometimes you can check your gear places. When I was in Sydney For a while there was a free museum that required you to check your bags when you entered. We went for a morning tour, slipped out, then came back before close for a look at more artwork before picking up our bags.
data.author: JD Van Allen

data.text: love that brilliant idea
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: it was so nice for us as unicycle packpackers. It took a lot of weight off of the saddle while we toured the city freely.
data.author: JD Van Allen

data.text: When we biked through Glacier NP, we wanted to do an overnight hike out one of the trails from our campground spot. We talked the guys at the fire station into storing our bikes in the back. Worked out great.
data.author: Mark Krause

data.text: nice one
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: If I wanted to do what your talking about i think you better on a campsite. Much less chance of everything you own going missing. I think biking and wild camping is about the journey not destinations. Would never leave my gear out of my sight.
data.author: Peter Whillians

data.text: If Iâ€™m at an established campground, I leave my tent set up with sleeping bag, etc in it, & take my electronics & any other small, high-value items with me. If Iâ€™m going on an overnight hike, it really depends where I am, but in wilderness areas, well away from communities, Iâ€™ve walked well off trail in the forest, locked my bike to a tree, covered it with a dark green tarp & stashed my bags.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: cheers im thinking of stopping on campsites tbh im not too im not too precious about my stuff. Im not letting scroates dictate my life. I pay insurance for possessions outside of the house. No point paying for insurance if you never going to use it.
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: If I'm wanting to leave my stuff in a town for a while I often leave my belonging with the bellhop at a nice hotel and tip them a bit, or a friendly business I just patronized, like a bike shop, outdoor gear shop, pub, barber or museum. Ask around and you will be surprised how helpful people are and how often there is a little closet or safe spot to put your stuff.
data.author: Morgan Rucks

data.text: brilliant thanks
data.author: Kev Trueman

data.text: do all that another day, and just enjoy the outdoors
data.author: Hook Dwyer

data.text: Bring some ice n some liquor or beer to the campsite. Problem solved.dont forget to bring some herb also.
data.author: Norbe Alatorre

data.text: Depends on the country of course. If wild camping, always find a camping place at least somehow hidden. Then you can leave your stuff there. Money and passport to be carried with you all the time.
